attributes.text:
This is the base class for all widgets.

External Documentation

Documentation of this widget in the qooxdoo manual.

NOTE: Instances of this class must be disposed of after use
When the widget gets active (receives keyboard events etc.)
Fired after the widget appears on the screen.
Widget is clicked using a non primary button. {@link qx.event.type.Mouse#getButton} for more details.
Fired before the context menu is opened.
The event is fired when the widget gets blurred. Only widgets which are {@link #focusable} receive this event.
Fired if the widget becomes the capturing widget by a call to {@link #capture}.
Fired on change of the property {@link #appearance}.
Fired on change of the property {@link #backgroundColor}.
Fired on change of the property {@link #contextMenu}.
Fired on change of the property {@link #decorator}.
Fired on change of the property {@link #enabled}.
Fired on change of the property {@link #font}.
Fired on change of the property {@link #nativeContextMenu}.
Fired on change of the property {@link #selectable}.
Fired on change of the property {@link #textColor}.
Fired on change of the property {@link #toolTipText}.
Fired on change of the property {@link #toolTipIcon}.
Fired on change of the property {@link #visibility}.
Fired on change of the property {@link #zIndex}.
Widget is clicked using left or middle button. {@link qx.event.type.Mouse#getButton} for more details.
Widget is clicked using the right mouse button.
Fired after the creation of a child control. The passed data is the newly created child widget.
Widget is double clicked using left or middle button. {@link qx.event.type.Mouse#getButton} for more details.
Fired when a pointer taps twice on the screen.
When the widget gets inactive
Fired after the widget disappears from the screen.

Fired during the drag. Contains the current pointer coordinates using {@link qx.event.type.Drag#getDocumentLeft} and {@link qx.event.type.Drag#getDocumentTop}

Modeled after the WHATWG specification of Drag&Drop: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#dnd

Fired when the drag configuration has been modified e.g. the user pressed a key which changed the selected action. This event will be fired on the draggable and the droppable element. In case of the droppable element, you can cancel the event and prevent a drop based on e.g. the current action.
Fired on the source (drag) target every time a drag session was ended.

Fired on a potential drop target when leaving it.

Modeled after the WHATWG specification of Drag&Drop: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#dnd

Fired on a potential drop target when reaching it via the pointer. This event can be canceled if none of the incoming data types are supported.

Modeled after the WHATWG specification of Drag&Drop: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#dnd

Initiate the drag-and-drop operation. This event is cancelable when the drag operation is currently not allowed/possible.

Modeled after the WHATWG specification of Drag&Drop: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#dnd

Fired on the drop target when the drag&drop action is finished successfully. This event is normally used to transfer the data from the drag to the drop target.

Modeled after the WHATWG specification of Drag&Drop: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#dnd

Fired when the drop was successfully done and the target widget is now asking for data. The listener should transfer the data, respecting the selected action, to the event. This can be done using the event’s {@link qx.event.type.Drag#addData} method.
The event is fired when the widget gets focused. Only widgets which are {@link #focusable} receive this event.
When the widget itself or any child of the widget receive the focus.
When the widget itself or any child of the widget lost the focus.
This event if fired if a keyboard key is pressed down. This event is only fired once if the user keeps the key pressed for a while.

This event is fired if the pressed key or keys result in a printable character. Since the character is not necessarily associated with a single physical key press, the event does not have a key identifier getter. This event gets repeated if the user keeps pressing the key(s).

The unicode code of the pressed key can be read using {@link qx.event.type.KeyInput#getCharCode}.
This event is fired any time a key is pressed. It will be repeated if the user keeps the key pressed. The pressed key can be determined using {@link qx.event.type.KeySequence#getKeyIdentifier}.
This event if fired if a keyboard key is released.
Fired when a pointer holds on the screen.
Fired if the widget looses the capturing mode by a call to {@link #releaseCapture} or a mouse click.
Mouse button is pressed on the widget.
Fired if the mouse cursor moves over the widget. The data property of the event contains the widget’s computed location and dimension as returned by {@link qx.ui.core.LayoutItem#getBounds}

Fired if the mouse cursor leaves widget.

Note: This event is also dispatched if the widget is disabled!

Fired if the mouse cursor enters the widget.

Note: This event is also dispatched if the widget is disabled!
Mouse button is released on the widget.
Fired if the mouse wheel is used over the widget.
Fired on move (after layout) of the widget. The data property of the event contains the widget’s computed location and dimension as returned by {@link qx.ui.core.LayoutItem#getBounds}
Fired when two pointers performing a pinch in/out gesture on the screen.
Fired if a pointer (mouse/touch/pen) action is canceled.
Fired if a pointer (mouse/touch/pen) button is pressed or a finger touches the widget.
Fired if a pointer (mouse/touch/pen) moves or changes any of it’s values.
Fired if a pointer (mouse/touch/pen) leaves this widget.
Fired if a pointer (mouse/touch/pen) hovers the widget.
Fired if all pointer (mouse/touch/pen) buttons are released or the finger is lifted from the widget.
Fired on resize (after layout) of the widget. The data property of the event contains the widget’s computed location and dimension as returned by {@link qx.ui.core.LayoutItem#getBounds}
Fired when an active pointer moves on the screen or the mouse wheel is used.
Fired when two pointers performing a rotate gesture on the screen.
Fired when a pointer swipes over the screen.

Fired after the appearance has been applied. This happens before the widget becomes visible, on state and appearance changes. The data field contains the state map. This can be used to react on state changes or to read properties set by the appearance.
Fired when a pointer taps on the screen.
Fired if a touch at the screen is canceled.
Fired if a touch at the screen has ended.
Fired during a touch at the screen.
Fired if a touch at the screen is started.
Fired when an active pointer moves on the screen (after pointerdown till pointerup).
The child to add.
Optional layout data for the widget.
Convenience function to add a child widget. It will insert the child to the parent widget and schedule a layout update.
Create the widget’s content HTML element.
The content HTML element
The child to remove.
Convenience function to remove a child widget. It will remove it from the parent widget and schedule a layout update.
The name of the css padding property e.g. paddingTop
The value to set.
Helper to updated the css padding of the content element considering the padding of the decorator.
the widget to add.
Optional layout data for widget.

Adds a new child widget.

The supported keys of the layout options map depend on the layout manager used to position the widget. The options are documented in the class documentation of each layout manager {@link qx.ui.layout}.
widget to add
widget, after which the new widget will be inserted
Optional layout data for widget.
Add a widget after another already inserted widget
widget to add
Index, at which the widget will be inserted. If no widget exists at the given index, the new widget gets appended to the current list of children.
Optional layout data for widget.
Add a child widget at the specified index
widget to add
widget before the new widget will be inserted.
Optional layout data for widget.
Add a widget before another already inserted widget
The added child.
This method gets called each time after a child widget was added and can be overridden to get notified about child adds.
The removed child.
This method gets called each time after a child widget was removed and can be overridden to get notified about child removes.
new value of the property
previous value of the property (null if it was not yet set).

ID of the child control

Force the creation of the given child control by ID.

Do not override this method! Override {@link #_createChildControlImpl} instead if you need to support new controls.
The created control
when the control was created before
ID of the child control. If a # is used, the id is the part in front of the #.
If a child control name contains a #, all text following the # will be the hash argument.
Internal method to create child controls. This method should be overwritten by classes which extends this one to support new child control types.
The created control or null

Creates the content element. The style properties position and zIndex are modified from the Widget core.

This function may be overridden to customize a class content.
The widget’s content element
Dispose all registered controls. This is automatically executed by the widget.
ID of the child control
Excludes the given child control by ID
Finds and returns the top level control. This is the first widget which is not a child control of any other widget.
The top control
Returns the children list
The children array (Arrays are reference types, so please do not modify it in-place).
Incoming width (as limitation)
Returns the computed height for the given width.
Computed height while respecting the given width.

Returns the recommended/natural dimensions of the widget’s content.

For labels and images this may be their natural size when defined without any dimensions. For containers this may be the recommended size of the underlying layout manager.

Developer note: This can be overwritten by the derived classes to allow a custom handling here.
Returns a map of all already created child controls
mapping of child control id to the child widget.
Helper to return a instance of a {@link qx.ui.core.DragDropCursor}. If you want to use your own DragDropCursor, override this method and return your custom instance.
A drag drop cursor implementation.
Whether the widget contains children.
Returns true when the widget has children.
the widget to query for
Returns the index position of the given widget if it is a child widget. Otherwise it returns -1.
The index position or -1 when the given widget is no child of this layout.
ID of the child control
Whether the given child control is visible.
true when the child control is visible.
The data event
Event listener for beforeContextmenuOpen event
The event object
Event listener for contextmenu event
Drag event
Event listener for own drag event.
Drag event
Event listener for own dragchange event.
Drag event
Event listener for own dragend event.
Drag event
Event listener for own dragstart event.
Any bubbling event
Event listener which stops a bubbling event from propagates further.
ID of the child control
Release the child control by ID and decouple the child from the parent. This method does not dispose the child control.
The released control
the widget to remove
Remove the given child widget.
Remove all children.
An array containing the removed children.
Index of the widget to remove.
Remove the widget at the specified index.
The removed item.
The new layout or null to reset the layout.
Set a layout manager for the widget. A a layout manager can only be connected with one widget. Reset the connection with a previous widget first, if you like to use it in another widget instead.
ID of the child control
Shows the given child control by ID
the child control
Activate this widget e.g. for keyboard events.
The queue to add widgets to
Recursively adds all children to the given queue
The state to add
Sets a state.
Remove focus from this widget.
If true all events originating in the container are captured. If false events originating in the container are not captured.

Enables pointer event capturing. All pointer events will dispatched on this widget until capturing is disabled using {@link #releaseCapture} or a pointer button is clicked. If the widgets becomes the capturing widget the {@link #capture} event is fired. Once it loses capture mode the {@link #losecapture} event is fired.
Helper method called from the visibility queue to detect outstanding changes to the appearance.
Deactivate this widget e.g. for keyboard events.

Removes this widget from its parent and disposes it.

Please note that the widget is not disposed synchronously. The real dispose happens after the next queue flush.
Hide this widget and exclude it from the underlying layout.
Time in ms.
Fade in the widget.
The animation handle to react for the fade animation.
Time in ms.
Fade out this widget.
The animation handle to react for the fade animation.
Focus this widget.

Returns the (computed) value of the property anonymous.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #anonymous}.
(Computed) value of anonymous.

Returns the (computed) value of the property appearance.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #appearance}.
(Computed) value of appearance.

Returns the (computed) value of the property backgroundColor.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #backgroundColor}.
(Computed) value of backgroundColor.

Returns the (computed) value of the property blockToolTip.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #blockToolTip}.
(Computed) value of blockToolTip.
ID of the child control
Whether the child control should not be created dynamically if not yet available.

Returns the child control from the given ID. Returns null when the child control is unknown.

It is designed for widget authors, who want to access child controls, which are created by the widget itself.

Warning: This method exposes widget internals and modifying the returned sub widget may bring the widget into an inconsistent state. Accessing child controls defined in a super class or in an foreign class is not supported. Do not use it if the result can be achieved using public API or theming.
Child control
Returns the widget which contains the children and is relevant for laying them out. This is from the user point of view and may not be identical to the technical structure.
Widget which contains the children.
Returns the element wrapper of the widget’s content element. This method exposes widget internal and must be used with caution!
The widget’s content element
A supported option. See comment above.

Computes the location of the content element in context of the document dimensions.

Supported modes:

  • margin: Calculate from the margin box of the element
    (bigger than the visual appearance: including margins of given element)
  • box: Calculates the offset box of the element (default,
    uses the same size as visible)
  • border: Calculate the border box (useful to align to
    border edges of two elements).
  • scroll: Calculate the scroll box (relevant for absolute
    positioned content).
  • padding: Calculate the padding box (relevant for
    static/relative positioned content).
Returns a map with left, top, right and bottom which contains the distance of the element relative to the document.

Returns the (computed) value of the property contextMenu.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #contextMenu}.

Returns the (computed) value of the property cursor.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #cursor}.

Returns the (computed) value of the property decorator.

Returns the (computed) value of the property enabled.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #enabled}.
(Computed) value of enabled.
Returns the next event target in the parent chain. May also return the widget itself if it is not anonymous.
A working event target of this widget. May be null as well.

Returns the (computed) value of the property focusable.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #focusable}.
(Computed) value of focusable.
Returns the element which should be focused.
The html element to focus.
Returns the next focus target in the parent chain. May also return the widget itself if it is not anonymous and focusable.
A working focus target of this widget. May be null as well.

Returns the (computed) value of the property font.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #font}.
(Computed) value of font.

Returns the widget’s computed inner size as available through the layout process.

This function is guaranteed to return a correct value during a {@link #resize} or {@link #move} event dispatch.
The widget inner dimension in pixel (if the layout is valid). Contains the keys width and height.
Returns the sum of the widget’s padding and border width.
Contains the keys top, right, bottom and left. All values are integers.

Returns the (computed) value of the property keepActive.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #keepActive}.
(Computed) value of keepActive.

Returns the (computed) value of the property keepFocus.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #keepFocus}.
(Computed) value of keepFocus.
Returns all children, which are layout relevant. This excludes all widgets, which have a {@link qx.ui.core.Widget#visibility} value of exclude.
All layout relevant children.

Returns the (computed) value of the property nativeContextMenu.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #nativeContextMenu}.
(Computed) value of nativeContextMenu.

Returns the (computed) value of the property opacity.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #opacity}.

Returns the (computed) value of the property paddingBottom.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #paddingBottom}.
(Computed) value of paddingBottom.

Returns the (computed) value of the property paddingLeft.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #paddingLeft}.

Returns the (computed) value of the property paddingRight.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #paddingRight}.

Returns the (computed) value of the property paddingTop.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #paddingTop}.
(Computed) value of paddingTop.

Returns the (computed) value of the property selectable.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #selectable}.
(Computed) value of selectable.

Returns the (computed) value of the property showToolTipWhenDisabled.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #showToolTipWhenDisabled}.
(Computed) value of showToolTipWhenDisabled.

Return the ID (name) if this instance was a created as a child control of another widget.

See the first parameter id in {@link qx.ui.core.Widget#_createChildControlImpl}
ID of the current widget or null if it was not created as a subcontrol

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #tabIndex}.

ID of the child control
Whether the given ID is assigned to a child control.
true when the child control is registered.
Returns whether the layout has children, which are layout relevant. This excludes all widgets, which have a {@link qx.ui.core.Widget#visibility} value of exclude.
Whether the layout has layout relevant children
the state to check.
Returns whether a state is set.
whether the state is set.
Hide this widget.
Initial value for property anonymous.

Marks the layout of this widget as invalid and triggers a layout update. This is a shortcut for qx.ui.core.queue.Layout.add(this);.
Child to scroll into view
Alignment of the item. Allowed values: left or right. Could also be null. Without a given alignment the method tries to scroll the widget with the minimum effort needed.
Alignment of the item. Allowed values: top or bottom. Could also be null. Without a given alignment the method tries to scroll the widget with the minimum effort needed.
Whether the execution should be made directly when possible
The method scrolls the given item into view.
Child to scroll into view
Alignment of the item. Allowed values: left or right. Could also be null. Without a given alignment the method tries to scroll the widget with the minimum effort needed.
Whether the execution should be made directly when possible
The method scrolls the given item into view (x-axis only).
Child to scroll into view
Alignment of the element. Allowed values: top or bottom. Could also be null. Without a given alignment the method tries to scroll the widget with the minimum effort needed.
Whether the execution should be made directly when possible
The method scrolls the given item into view (y-axis only).

Left position

Directly modifies the relative left position in relation to the parent element.

Use with caution! This may be used for animations, drag&drop or other cases where high performance location manipulation is important. Otherwise please use {@link qx.ui.core.LayoutItem#setUserBounds} instead.
Left position
Top position

Directly modifies the relative left and top position in relation to the parent element.

Use with caution! This may be used for animations, drag&drop or other cases where high performance location manipulation is important. Otherwise please use {@link qx.ui.core.LayoutItem#setUserBounds} instead.
Top position

Directly modifies the relative top position in relation to the parent element.

Use with caution! This may be used for animations, drag&drop or other cases where high performance location manipulation is important. Otherwise please use {@link qx.ui.core.LayoutItem#setUserBounds} instead.

Refreshes the appearance of this widget and all registered child controls.

Event handler which is executed when the widget lost the focus.

This method is used by the {@link qx.ui.core.FocusHandler} to remove states etc. from a previously focused widget.

Event handler which is executed when the widget receives the focus.

This method is used by the {@link qx.ui.core.FocusHandler} to apply states etc. to a focused widget.

Whether the widget is anonymous.

Anonymous widgets are ignored in the event hierarchy. This is useful for combined widgets where the internal structure do not have a custom appearance with a different styling from the element around. This is especially true for widgets like checkboxes or buttons where the text or icon are handled synchronously for state changes to the outer widget.
The appearance ID. This ID is used to identify the appearance theme entry to use for this widget. This controls the styling of the element.
The background color the rendered widget.
Controls if a tooltip should shown or not.
Whether to show a context menu and which one

Mapping to native style property cursor.

The name of the cursor to show when the pointer is over the widget. This is any valid CSS2 cursor name defined by W3C.

The following values are possible crossbrowser:

  • default
  • crosshair
  • pointer
  • move
  • n-resize
  • ne-resize
  • e-resize
  • se-resize
  • s-resize
  • sw-resize
  • w-resize
  • nw-resize
  • nesw-resize
  • nwse-resize
  • text
  • wait
  • help

The decorator property points to an object, which is responsible for drawing the widget’s decoration, e.g. border, background or shadow.

This can be a decorator object or a string pointing to a decorator defined in the decoration theme.
Whether the widget acts as a source for drag&drop operations
Whether the widget acts as a target for drag&drop operations

Whether the widget is enabled. Disabled widgets are usually grayed out and do not process user created events. While in the disabled state most user input events are blocked. Only the {@link #pointerover} and {@link #pointerout} events will be dispatched.

Whether the widget is focusable e.g. rendering a focus border and visualize as active element.

See also {@link #isTabable} which allows runtime checks for isChecked or other stuff to test whether the widget is reachable via the TAB key.
The widget’s font. The value is either a font name defined in the font theme or an instance of {@link qx.bom.Font}.

If this property if enabled, the widget and all of its child widgets will never get activated. The activation keeps at the currently activated widget.

This is mainly useful for widget authors. Please use with caution!

If this property is enabled, the widget and all of its child widgets will never get focused. The focus keeps at the currently focused widget.

This only works for widgets which are not {@link #focusable}.

This is mainly useful for widget authors. Please use with caution!

Whether the native context menu should be enabled for this widget. To globally enable the native context menu set the {@link #nativeContextMenu} property of the root widget ({@link qx.ui.root.Abstract}) to true.

Mapping to native style property opacity.

The uniform opacity setting to be applied across an entire object. Behaves like the new CSS-3 Property. Any values outside the range 0.0 (fully transparent) to 1.0 (fully opaque) will be clamped to this range.

The ‘padding’ property is a shorthand property for setting ‘paddingTop’, ‘paddingRight’, ‘paddingBottom’ and ‘paddingLeft’ at the same time.

If four values are specified they apply to top, right, bottom and left respectively. If there is only one value, it applies to all sides, if there are two or three, the missing values are taken from the opposite side.
Padding of the widget (bottom)
Padding of the widget (left)
Padding of the widget (right)
Padding of the widget (top)

Whether the widget contains content which may be selected by the user.

If the value set to true the native browser selection can be used for text selection. But it is normally useful for forms fields, longer texts/documents, editors, etc.
Forces to show tooltip when widget is disabled.

Defines the tab index of an widget. If widgets with tab indexes are part of the current focus root these elements are sorted in first priority. Afterwards the sorting continues by rendered position, zIndex and other criteria.

Please note: The value must be between 1 and 32000.
The text color the rendered widget.

Sets the tooltip instance to use for this widget. If only the tooltip text and icon have to be set its better to use the {@link #toolTipText} and {@link #toolTipIcon} properties since they use a shared tooltip instance.

If this property is set the {@link #toolTipText} and {@link #toolTipIcon} properties are ignored.

The icon URI of the widget’s tooltip. This icon is displayed using a shared tooltip instance. If the tooltip must be customized beyond the tooltip text {@link #toolTipText} and the icon, the {@link #toolTip} property has to be used.

The text of the widget’s tooltip. This text can contain HTML markup. The text is displayed using a shared tooltip instance. If the tooltip must be customized beyond the text and an icon {@link #toolTipIcon}, the {@link #toolTip} property has to be used

Controls the visibility. Valid values are:

  • visible: Render the widget
  • hidden: Hide the widget but don't relayout the widget's parent.
  • excluded: Hide the widget and relayout the parent as if the widget was not a child of its parent.
The z-index property sets the stack order of an element. An element with greater stack order is always in front of another element with lower stack order.
Whether the widget should print out hints and debug messages
Contains all pooled separators for reuse
The parent widget
The child widget
Whether the “parent” widget contains the “child” widget.
Whether one of the “child”‘s parents is “parent”
The DOM element to search the widget for.
If true, anonymous widget will not be returned.
Returns the widget, which contains the given DOM element.
The widget containing the element.
